title: MARKET SNAPSHOT: Amazon, Other Tech Stocks Set To Lead Wall Street Gains
text:
By Barbara Kollmeyer, MarketWatch
Microsoft, Alphabet climb in thin premarket trading
Upbeat results from major technology companies were expected to give the Nasdaq Composite Index an early boost on Friday, while other major indexes also looked set for moderate gains on the heels of a strong rally..
Dow industrials futures rose 76 points, or 0.4%, to 17,485, while those for the S&P 500 index added 7.9 points, or 0.4%, to 2,061. Futures for the Nasdaq-100 index jumped 31.50 points, or 0.7%, to 4,584.25, as shares of Amazon.com, Alphabet Inc. and Microsoft Corp. looked set to rally after earnings late Thursday.
"The average between the three of these firms was an after-hours share price boost of over 10%, with Microsoft hitting a 15-year high," said Alastair McCaig, senior market analyst at IG, in a note.
Fueled by better-than-expected corporate results and hints of more easing measures from European Central Bank President Mario Draghi (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/ecbs-draghi-opens-door-for-more-qe-in-december-2015-10-22), stocks finished sharply higher on Thursday. The Dow industrials closed up 320.55 points, or 1.9%, at 17,489.16, the biggest point and percentage gain since Sept. 8.
Moderate gains for U.S. stock futures came as European stocks continued to rally on Friday. The latest relief rally for Wall Street retraced about half the "panic attack" since China devalued the yuan, said Ed Yardeni, chief investment strategist at Yardeni Research, in a note. The S&P 500 is now above its Aug. 25 closing low and 4.6% below its May 21 record high, he noted.
But investors may start turning their attention soon to a busy week for central banks next week, with the Federal Open Market Committee meeting Oct. 27 and 28, and the Bank of Japan holding its own monetary policy meeting on Oct. 30.
Read: The best six months for stocks is about to begin (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/the-best-six-months-for-stocks-is-about-to-begin-2015-10-23)
Upbeat tech: Shares of Amazon(AMZN) could add to an 11% late-session surge after the e-commerce giant announced a surprise profit for the third quarter (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/amazon-posts-surprise-profit-while-sales-surge-2015-10-22-16485258), and forecast an operating profit for the holiday quarter.
Alphabet (GOOGL), formerly known as Google, announced its first-ever stock buyback plan (http://blogs.marketwatch.com/thetell/2015/10/22/live-blog-google-to-report-first-earnings-as-alphabet/), and will spend more than $5 billion buying back shares.
Read: Are tech rebels Amazon and Alphabet finally growing up? (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/are-tech-rebels-amazon-and-alphabet-finally-growing-up-2015-10-22)
(http://www.marketwatch.com/story/are-tech-rebels-amazon-and-alphabet-finally-growing-up-2015-10-22)Microsoft(MSFT) reported better-than-expected profit and revenue (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/microsoft-profit-buoyed-by-lower-costs-2015-10-22) late Thursday, pushing up shares in late trading.
Also in the news Friday, Twitter Inc.'s(TWTR) chief executive officer Jack Dorsey, said he will give nearly $200 million of his own shares (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/twitters-jack-dorsey-gives-workers-nearly-200-million-of-his-own-shares-2015-10-23) -- 1% of the company -- to the employee stock pool.
American Airlines Group Inc. (AAL) and Procter & Gamble Co.(PG) will report results on Friday.
Other markets: The Stoxx Europe 600 index (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/european-stocks-on-pace-to-third-straight-weekly-gain-2015-10-23) was headed for its third straight weekly gain, up 1.3% as the market coasted on the potential for more stimulus from the ECB. A flash reading of October manufacturing activity in the eurozone (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/eurozone-pmi-gains-suggests-no-china-impact-yet-2015-10-23) came in higher than expected.
Asian markets (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/nikkei-hang-seng-climb-on-hopes-for-more-stimulus-in-europe-2015-10-23) also saw sharp gains across the board, with the Shanghai Composite Index rising 1.2%. The Nikkei 225 index closed up 2.1% as the Japanese yen continued to weaken against the U.S. dollar (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/euro-extends-losses-investors-turn-to-next-weeks-fomc-meeting-2015-10-23). The euro also remained on a weaker footing against the U.S. currency.
Gold prices rose about 0.5% to $1,172.20 an ounce, while crude oil (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/oil-prices-rise-but-stronger-dollar-lurks-in-the-background-2015-10-23) made moderate gains.
